cn.name: json_rpc_2.Client

methods.name: Client
methods.desc:
Creates a Client that communicates over channel.

Note that the client won't begin listening to responses until Client.listen is called.

methods.name: close
methods.desc:
Closes the underlying connection.

Returns a Future that completes when all resources have been released. This is the same as done.

methods.name: listen
methods.desc:
Starts listening to the underlying stream.

Returns a Future that will complete when the connection is closed or when it has an error. This is the same as done.

listen may only be called once.

methods.name: sendNotification
methods.desc:
Sends a JSON-RPC 2 request to invoke the given method without expecting a response.

If passed, parameters is the parameters for the method. This must be either an Iterable (to pass parameters by position) or a Map with String keys (to pass parameters by name). Either way, it must be JSON-serializable.

Since this is just a notification to which the server isn't expected to send a response, it has no return value.

Throws a StateError if the client is closed when this method is called.

methods.name: sendRequest
methods.desc:
Sends a JSON-RPC 2 request to invoke the given method.

If passed, parameters is the parameters for the method. This must be either an Iterable (to pass parameters by position) or a Map with String keys (to pass parameters by name). Either way, it must be JSON-serializable.

If the request succeeds, this returns the response result as a decoded JSON-serializable object. If it fails, it throws an RpcException describing the failure.

Throws a StateError if the client is closed while the request is in flight, or if the client is closed when this method is called.
methods.example:
Implementation

Future sendRequest(String method, [parameters]) {
  var id = _id++;
  _send(method, parameters, id);

  var completer = new Completer.sync();
  _pendingRequests[id] = new _Request(method, completer, new Chain.current());
  return completer.future;
}

methods.name: withBatch
methods.desc:
Runs callback and batches any requests sent until it returns.

A batch of requests is sent in a single message on the underlying stream, and the responses are likewise sent back in a single message.

callback may be synchronous or asynchronous. If it returns a Future, requests will be batched until that Future returns; otherwise, requests will only be batched while synchronously executing callback.

If this is called in the context of another withBatch call, it just invokes callback without creating another batch. This means that responses are batched until the first batch ends.
methods.example:
Implementation

withBatch(callback()) {
  if (_batch != null) return callback();

  _batch = [];
  return tryFinally(callback, () {
    _manager.add(_batch);
    _batch = null;
  });
}

methods.name: Client.withoutJson
methods.desc:
Creates a Client that communicates using decoded messages over channel.

Unlike new Client, this doesn't read or write JSON strings. Instead, it reads and writes decoded maps or lists.

Note that the client won't begin listening to responses until Client.listen is called.
methods.example:
Implementation

Client.withoutJson(StreamChannel channel)
    : _manager = new ChannelManager("Client", channel) {
  _manager.done.whenComplete(() {
    for (var request in _pendingRequests.values) {
      request.completer.completeError(
          new StateError(
              'The client closed with pending request "${request.method}".'),
          StackTrace.current);
    }
    _pendingRequests.clear();
  }).catchError((_) {
    // Avoid an unhandled error.
  });
}

props.name: done
props.desc:
Returns a Future that completes when the underlying connection is closed.

This is the same future that's returned by listen and close. It may complete before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

props.name: isClosed
props.desc:
Whether the underlying connection is closed.

Note that this will be true before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

cn.desc:
A JSON-RPC 2.0 client.

A client calls methods on a server and handles the server's responses to those method calls. Methods can be called with sendRequest, or with sendNotification if no response is expected.

cn.name: json_rpc_2.Parameter

methods.name: asBoolOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is a boolean and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asDateTimeOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value exists, is a string, and can be parsed as a DateTime and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asIntOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is an integer and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

Note that which values count as integers varies between the Dart VM and dart2js. The value 1.0 will be considered an integer under dart2js but not under the VM.

methods.name: asListOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is a List and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asMapOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is a Map and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asNumOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is a number and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asStringOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value is a string and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: asUriOr
methods.desc:
Asserts that value exists, is a string, and can be parsed as a Uri and returns it.

If value doesn't exist, this returns defaultValue.

methods.name: valueOr
methods.desc: Returns value, or defaultValue if this parameter wasn't passed.

props.name: asBool
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is a boolean and returns it.

asBoolOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.
props.example:
Implementation

bool get asBool => _getTyped('a boolean', (value) => value is bool);

props.name: asDateTime
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists, is a string, and can be parsed as a DateTime and returns it.

asDateTimeOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.

props.name: asInt
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is an integer and returns it.

asIntOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.

Note that which values count as integers varies between the Dart VM and dart2js. The value 1.0 will be considered an integer under dart2js but not under the VM.
props.example:
Implementation

int get asInt => _getTyped('an integer', (value) => value is int);

props.name: asList
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is a List and returns it.

asListOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.
props.example:
Implementation

List get asList => _getTyped('an Array', (value) => value is List);

props.name: asMap
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is a Map and returns it.

asMapOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.
props.example:
Implementation

Map get asMap => _getTyped('an Object', (value) => value is Map);

props.name: asNum
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is a number and returns it.

asNumOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.
props.example:
Implementation

num get asNum => _getTyped('a number', (value) => value is num);

props.name: asString
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists and is a string and returns it.

asStringOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.
props.example:
Implementation

String get asString => _getTyped('a string', (value) => value is String);

props.name: asUri
props.desc:
Asserts that value exists, is a string, and can be parsed as a Uri and returns it.

asUriOr may be used to provide a default value instead of rejecting the request if value doesn't exist.

props.name: exists
props.desc: Whether this parameter exists.

cn.desc:
A wrapper for a single parameter to a server method.

This provides numerous functions for asserting the type of the parameter in question. These functions each have a version that asserts that the parameter exists (for example, asNum and asString) and a version that returns a default value if the parameter doesn't exist (for example, asNumOr and asStringOr). If an assertion fails, the request is automatically rejected.

This extends Parameters to make it easy to access nested parameters. For example:

// "params.value" is "{'scores': {'home': [5, 10, 17]}}"
params['scores']['home'][2].asInt // => 17

cn.name: json_rpc_2.Parameters

methods.name: operator []
methods.desc:
Returns a single parameter.

If key is a String, the request is expected to provide named parameters. If it's an int, the request is expected to provide positional parameters. Requests that don't do so will be rejected automatically.

Whether or not the given parameter exists, this returns a Parameter object. If a parameter's value is accessed through a getter like value or Parameter.asNum, the request will be rejected if that parameter doesn't exist. On the other hand, if it's accessed through a method with a default value like Parameter.valueOr or Parameter.asNumOr, the default value will be returned.
methods.example:
Implementation

Parameter operator [](key) {
  if (key is int) {
    _assertPositional();
    if (key < value.length) {
      return new Parameter._(method, value[key], this, key);
    } else {
      return new _MissingParameter(method, this, key);
    }
  } else if (key is String) {
    _assertNamed();
    if (value.containsKey(key)) {
      return new Parameter._(method, value[key], this, key);
    } else {
      return new _MissingParameter(method, this, key);
    }
  } else {
    throw new ArgumentError('Parameters[] only takes an int or a string, was '
        '"$key".');
  }
}

props.name: asList
props.desc: Asserts that value exists and is a List and returns it.
props.example:
Implementation

List get asList {
  _assertPositional();
  return value;
}

props.name: asMap
props.desc: Asserts that value exists and is a Map and returns it.
props.example:
Implementation

Map get asMap {
  _assertNamed();
  return value;
}

props.name: method
props.desc: The name of the method that this request called.

props.name: value
props.desc:
The underlying value of the parameters object.

If this is accessed for a Parameter that was not passed, the request will be automatically rejected. To avoid this, use Parameter.valueOr.

cn.desc:
A wrapper for the parameters to a server method.

JSON-RPC 2.0 allows parameters that are either a list or a map. This class provides functions that not only assert that the parameters object is the correct type, but also that the expected arguments exist and are themselves the correct type.

Example usage:

server.registerMethod("subtract", (params) {
  return params["minuend"].asNum - params["subtrahend"].asNum;
});

cn.name: json_rpc_2.Peer

methods.name: Peer
methods.desc:
Creates a Peer that communicates over channel.

Note that the peer won't begin listening to channel until Peer.listen is called.

methods.name: close
methods.desc:
Closes the underlying connection.

Returns a Future that completes when all resources have been released. This is the same as done.

methods.name: listen
methods.desc:
Starts listening to the underlying stream.

Returns a Future that will complete when the connection is closed or when it has an error. This is the same as done.

listen may only be called once.
methods.example:
Implementation

Future listen() {
  _client.listen();
  _server.listen();
  return _manager.listen((message) {
    if (message is Map) {
      if (message.containsKey('result') || message.containsKey('error')) {
        _clientIncomingForwarder.add(message);
      } else {
        _serverIncomingForwarder.add(message);
      }
    } else if (message is List &&
        message.isNotEmpty &&
        message.first is Map) {
      if (message.first.containsKey('result') ||
          message.first.containsKey('error')) {
        _clientIncomingForwarder.add(message);
      } else {
        _serverIncomingForwarder.add(message);
      }
    } else {
      // Non-Map and -List messages are ill-formed, so we pass them to the
      // server since it knows how to send error responses.
      _serverIncomingForwarder.add(message);
    }
  });
}

methods.name: registerFallback
methods.desc:
Registers a fallback method on this server.

A server may have any number of fallback methods. When a request comes in that doesn't match any named methods, each fallback is tried in order. A fallback can pass on handling a request by throwing a RpcException.methodNotFound exception.

callback can return either a JSON-serializable object or a Future that completes to a JSON-serializable object. Any errors in callback will be reported to the client as JSON-RPC 2.0 errors. callback may send custom errors by throwing an RpcException.

methods.name: registerMethod
methods.desc:
Registers a method named name on this server.

callback can take either zero or one arguments. If it takes zero, any requests for that method that include parameters will be rejected. If it takes one, it will be passed a Parameters object.

callback can return either a JSON-serializable object or a Future that completes to a JSON-serializable object. Any errors in callback will be reported to the client as JSON-RPC 2.0 errors.
methods.example:
Implementation

void registerMethod(String name, Function callback) =>
    _server.registerMethod(name, callback);

methods.name: sendNotification
methods.desc:
Sends a JSON-RPC 2 request to invoke the given method without expecting a response.

If passed, parameters is the parameters for the method. This must be either an Iterable (to pass parameters by position) or a Map with String keys (to pass parameters by name). Either way, it must be JSON-serializable.

Since this is just a notification to which the server isn't expected to send a response, it has no return value.

Throws a StateError if the client is closed when this method is called.

methods.name: sendRequest
methods.desc:
Sends a JSON-RPC 2 request to invoke the given method.

If passed, parameters is the parameters for the method. This must be either an Iterable (to pass parameters by position) or a Map with String keys (to pass parameters by name). Either way, it must be JSON-serializable.

If the request succeeds, this returns the response result as a decoded JSON-serializable object. If it fails, it throws an RpcException describing the failure.

Throws a StateError if the client is closed while the request is in flight, or if the client is closed when this method is called.

methods.name: withBatch
methods.desc:
Runs callback and batches any requests sent until it returns.

A batch of requests is sent in a single message on the underlying stream, and the responses are likewise sent back in a single message.

callback may be synchronous or asynchronous. If it returns a Future, requests will be batched until that Future returns; otherwise, requests will only be batched while synchronously executing callback.

If this is called in the context of another withBatch call, it just invokes callback without creating another batch. This means that responses are batched until the first batch ends.

methods.name: Peer.withoutJson
methods.desc:
Creates a Peer that communicates using decoded messages over channel.

Unlike new Peer, this doesn't read or write JSON strings. Instead, it reads and writes decoded maps or lists.

Note that the peer won't begin listening to channel until Peer.listen is called.
methods.example:
Implementation

Peer.withoutJson(StreamChannel channel)
    : _manager = new ChannelManager("Peer", channel) {
  _server = new Server.withoutJson(
      new StreamChannel(_serverIncomingForwarder.stream, channel.sink));
  _client = new Client.withoutJson(
      new StreamChannel(_clientIncomingForwarder.stream, channel.sink));
}

props.name: done
props.desc:
Returns a Future that completes when the underlying connection is closed.

This is the same future that's returned by listen and close. It may complete before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

props.name: isClosed
props.desc:
Whether the underlying connection is closed.

Note that this will be true before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

cn.desc:
A JSON-RPC 2.0 client and server.

This supports bidirectional peer-to-peer communication with another JSON-RPC 2.0 endpoint. It sends both requests and responses across the same communication channel and expects to connect to a peer that does the same.

cn.name: json_rpc_2.RpcException

methods.name: RpcException.invalidParams
methods.desc:
An exception indicating that the parameters for the requested method were invalid.

Methods can use this to reject requests with invalid parameters.

methods.name: RpcException.methodNotFound
methods.desc:
An exception indicating that the method named methodName was not found.

This should usually be used only by fallback handlers.

methods.name: serialize
methods.desc: Converts this exception into a JSON-serializable object that's a valid JSON-RPC 2.0 error response.
methods.example:
Implementation

serialize(request) {
  var modifiedData;
  if (data is Map && !data.containsKey('request')) {
    modifiedData = new Map.from(data);
    modifiedData['request'] = request;
  } else if (data == null) {
    modifiedData = {'request': request};
  } else {
    modifiedData = data;
  }

  var id = request is Map ? request['id'] : null;
  if (id is! String && id is! num) id = null;
  return {
    'jsonrpc': '2.0',
    'error': {'code': code, 'message': message, 'data': modifiedData},
    'id': id
  };
}

methods.name: toString
methods.desc: Returns a string representation of this object.
methods.example:
Implementation

String toString() {
  var prefix = "JSON-RPC error $code";
  var errorName = error_code.name(code);
  if (errorName != null) prefix += " ($errorName)";
  return "$prefix: $message";
}

props.name: code
props.desc:
The error code.

All non-negative error codes are available for use by application developers.

props.name: data
props.desc:
Extra application-defined information about the error.

This must be a JSON-serializable object. If it's a Map without a "request" key, a copy of the request that caused the error will automatically be injected.

props.name: message
props.desc:
The error message.

This should be limited to a concise single sentence. Further information should be supplied via data.

cn.desc: An exception from a JSON-RPC server that can be translated into an error response.

cn.name: json_rpc_2.Server

methods.name: Server
methods.desc:
Creates a Server that communicates over channel.

Note that the server won't begin listening to requests until Server.listen is called.

methods.name: close
methods.desc:
Closes the underlying connection.

Returns a Future that completes when all resources have been released. This is the same as done.

methods.name: listen
methods.desc:
Starts listening to the underlying stream.

Returns a Future that will complete when the connection is closed or when it has an error. This is the same as done.

listen may only be called once.

methods.name: registerFallback
methods.desc:
Registers a fallback method on this server.

A server may have any number of fallback methods. When a request comes in that doesn't match any named methods, each fallback is tried in order. A fallback can pass on handling a request by throwing a RpcException.methodNotFound exception.

callback can return either a JSON-serializable object or a Future that completes to a JSON-serializable object. Any errors in callback will be reported to the client as JSON-RPC 2.0 errors. callback may send custom errors by throwing an RpcException.

methods.name: registerMethod
methods.desc:
Registers a method named name on this server.

callback can take either zero or one arguments. If it takes zero, any requests for that method that include parameters will be rejected. If it takes one, it will be passed a Parameters object.

callback can return either a JSON-serializable object or a Future that completes to a JSON-serializable object. Any errors in callback will be reported to the client as JSON-RPC 2.0 errors.
methods.example:
Implementation

void registerMethod(String name, Function callback) {
  if (_methods.containsKey(name)) {
    throw new ArgumentError('There\'s already a method named "$name".');
  }

  _methods[name] = callback;
}

methods.name: Server.withoutJson
methods.desc:
Creates a Server that communicates using decoded messages over channel.

Unlike new Server, this doesn't read or write JSON strings. Instead, it reads and writes decoded maps or lists.

Note that the server won't begin listening to requests until Server.listen is called.

props.name: done
props.desc:
Returns a Future that completes when the underlying connection is closed.

This is the same future that's returned by listen and close. It may complete before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

props.name: isClosed
props.desc:
Whether the underlying connection is closed.

Note that this will be true before close is called if the remote endpoint closes the connection.

cn.desc:
A JSON-RPC 2.0 server.

A server exposes methods that are called by requests, to which it provides responses. Methods can be registered using registerMethod and registerFallback. Requests can be handled using handleRequest and parseRequest.

Note that since requests can arrive asynchronously and methods can run asynchronously, it's possible for multiple methods to be invoked at the same time, or even for a single method to be invoked multiple times at once.
